reviewText:
Final edit: I have played through both Jedi Knight and Mysteries of the Sith (the expansion). To do so I followed Steam user -FwG- ^ Bucky's instructions (thanks, man!). I had to roll back my AMD videocard drivers. This means I had to remove all current videocard drivers and install this, older, videocard driver: 13.1 WHQL, which can be found here: http://www.mediafire.com/download/s5tl45g6sce5wp7/AMD_Catalyst_13.1_Non-Legacy.zip

Also, I had to download a DLL file from the JKHub website, which can be found here: http://www.jkhub.net/project/get.php?id=1804. Put the file in the same folder where you JK.exe or Mots.exe is.
Don't forget to turn on hardware acceleration in the setup menu in-game.

So, does all of this change my opinion? Well, no. Jedi Knight and its expansion are awesome games, but the way Steam provides them to us is unacceptable. The amount of tweaking that has to be done, is quite severe. If you're not very technical or aren't allowed to change videocard drivers the game is unplayable on PC's with AMD cards.

Besides the tweaking, several issues remain. The cutscenes in Jedi Knight and Mysteries play in a minimized sceen in the top left corner of your screen and the soundtrack doesn't loop, leaving out music for an incredible large part of the game (a Star Wars game without the epic music?!).

If the game was playable as it was intended I would give it ten thumbs up, if I could. But in its current state on Steam, I cannot recommend it. The way Steam throws a broken version of a beautiful game online to be sold, without any heart for how much this game means to people, is unacceptable.



EDIT: After toying with videocard settings and in-game resolutions, I was able to get some gameplay out of it. Still, there are the crashes (when going to the menu screen and back), the small windows in which the menus and videos are shown, the ingame music that doesn't loop (tracks stop after one play-through, so the rest of the level is without music) and the lack of 3D accelaration.

So, contrary to what I stated in my review below, the game can be played, but not stable and with a poor audio and video presentation.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In short: are you running Windows 7, 64Bit with an AMD video card? Then the game will not run.

I'm really wondering if the positive reviews on this game's store page are by people that bought the game on Steam and are playing that or are they by people that remember the game from way back? I would think the latter. If I would have to grade it by how I remember it, it would have ten thumbs up. But now, through Steam not so much.

If you're using Windows 7, do not expect to install and play. It requires a lot of tweaking, downloading unofficial patches and files to get it running. At this time it is not possible to get it running like in the old days. The videos, for example, will only run in a small window in the upper left corner of your screen.

The thumbs down is more for Steam than for the game itself. I love the Kyle Katarn saga and this game was one of the finest in the series. But I feel cheated for buying this and I was so looking forward to this after finishing the first Dark Forces game.

I expect to buy something that works. I have very limited technical computer skills, so trying to make sense of how to get this game to work, is ruining my experience.
I'm now browsing through forums, downloading god knows what kind of files and trying anything to be able to play this game. Which I am still not able to.

With many other games I would have shrugged and just be bummed out. But this game is something special and deserves a proper Windows 7 compatible version. Come on, Steam, make it happen! (Maybe take a look at how GOG has its things sorted out).

reviewText:
Lively & nostalgic // Recommended for fans of Star Wars & retro gaming
+ Well-applied combination of first- and third-person elements; both are well-designed and practical in their implementation
+ Plethora of story-advancing cinematics; all include live action with actors, as well as some basic CGI work
+ Great soundtrack that is well-utilized
+ Excellent and franchise-friendly plot, helped along by competent writing; much improved from Dark Forces
+ Massively improved visuals compared to first installment
+ Level design, though still a bit convoluted at times, is nevertheless much improved; feels considerably more modern and refined than its predecessor
+ Unlockable force abilities, as well as an adequate weapon selection makes for slight variations in gameplay
+ Midway through the narrative, there is an option to persue either Light or Dark side; both affect playstyle and the nature of the narrative's conclusion

- Lightsaber combat and some decidedly overpowered force abilities make combat much too easy in many areas
- Some mission objectives and level designs prove a bit counterintuitive
- There were some hiccups when trying to set the game up to run on a modern machine; all were overcome, but it felt an unnecessary hastle

reviewText:
What is it with Nar Shadda? The place has featured at least three times over the course of the Dark Forces Saga and once in KOTOR II, and it was the weakest part of the game every time. There's just something about the Smuggler's Moon that lends itself to rubbish level design.

Anyway, after checking a few guides on getting the damn thing to run, I finally got Dark Forces II to play. The game starts out a bit rocky, as most of your ammunition is scavanaged off of your fallen enemies, an ineffective strategy when about half of your enemies come at you with good old fisticuffs. This led to a few occasions when I had to take out a dozen enemies with six blaster shots and my own punches, and sadly it seems Kyle hasn't been working out quite like he used to as the fists that could once drop a Kell Dragon are barely enough to put down passing thugs.

Fortunately once you get off Nar Shadda, enemies are universally packing heat, and the game starts to come to life. Ugly, early full-3D life, but life nonetheless. The level design is somewhere between the original Dark Force's nonlinear approach and Jedi Outcast's straight shot from start to finish, and manages to have the strengths and weaknesses of both. The levels are truly impressive in size, and lead to some memorable setpieces (most dramatic, if relatively brief, of which is a scene when you're left trying to sprint for the hangar bay of a ship in freefall), but they also follow a highly specific thread of advancement that, while not so bad as Dark Force's tendancy to block off progression to people who can't use sideways moon logic, still can leave you poking around a level for half an hour looking for the solitary path forward. Perhaps they felt the necessity due to the actual presence of maps in the game, but the locations beat out Jedi Outcasts in that their layout actually seems to have something to do with the location you're alledgedly visiting (for example, a starship whose rooms are actually laid out in the shape of a starship).

However, despite the strengths I mention, I ultimately can't recommend the game because its sprawling design isn't quite as good as Dark Forces, and its storyline isn't as good as Jedi Outcast's, lacking relatable characters and quite often much of a plot at all. For example, once you aquire a lightsaber from your father's droid, you start using Force powers without training, or indeed any exposition that you had any Force potential at all (the lightsaber isn't even your father's, so a hereditary connection isn't implied either). reviewText: Jedi Knight, the follow up FPS to Dark Forces was and still is one of the best FPS games to date.  The only thing that didn't age well in this game is the graphics.  The models can look horrible at times, but overall the immense levels create a sense of immersion rarely seen in games these days.  The level design is top notch, the length of each level is very long, and the variety of weapons is perfect.  This is a Star Wars game at its best.  The storyline is well done too, though the video produced cutscenes are cheesy at best, but at least they keep the story going, and the story gives you reason and meaning to why you are fighting.  I did have some issues with the game.  The amount of times that I died and had to restart from a save from a long time ago was very frustrating.  I wish this game had auto save, which would have been perfect when specific goals on your objectives were completed.  Also, the lack of the audio music from Star Wars (which was played from the CD in the original format) is absent in this Steam version.  I watched the credits without any Star Wars music, and throughout the game it was the same.\n\nThis game is a classic.  If you love Star Wars and don't mind the dated graphics, you're in for a great adventure.  Highly recommended.

Star Wars Jedi Knight Dark Forces II is one of the great old gems. You can replay it to this day and still enjoy it. Strong gameplay, good graphics for it's time, great difficulty, well made maps and some of the best live action cutscenes you'll ever find.

It's funny replaying this old gem, a shooter from a time when level design was sprawling and non-linear, where enemies were numerous and survival was actually difficult you start to notice things about modern games. One strange observation I've made, playing this again after so many years, is that I can see the path from this game directly through Bioware's modern aRPG's, from Jade Empire to Mass Effect 3 so much of it have it's roots in Lucasart's Jedi Knight series. It is a shame that they took the simple RPG elements and basic morality system instead of the superb shooter and exploration elements. Such a shame.

A really great game that everyone needs to have played.

It's a pity, really, that Jedi Knight tends to run badly on modern OSs. I don't recommend it for WIndows 8/10 PCs as it usually runs pretty badly. My WIndows 7 rig ran it without a lot of issues.

It's a pity, because the game is just absolutely fantastic. Levels are huge, but not empty, and make great use of verticality. The automap is great at showing you where you're supposed to go, and really gives you a much better idea of how big levels are.) There are a lot of nooks and crannies to explore throughout. The guns are satisfying, not great (Dark Forces I had better looking and feeling weapons IMO) , and the movement is really great, kinda like Quake's movement but with less momentum, handy, as JK tends to have more platforming and tight passages of which you don't want to fall out of. Force Powers are nothing special (This was before the prequel Trilogy, though), but some of them are well used in levels (especially Force Jump, but also Speed.) There are Dark Side (mostly damage-dealing) and Light Side (buffs/healing) It also has a lot of battles with Dark Jedi, but they're quite lackluster, since the lightsaber combat is pretty clunky.

The story consists mostly of live action cutscenes with some pretty cheesy acting, but pretty good overall (sadly, they run on what seems to be a 640x480 window on my PC, same as the menus.) The cool thing is that on about the last third of the game, you get locked into either Dark Side or Light Side. This will depend on how many innocents you've killed, and whether you invested in dark or light side force powers. Keeping mostly loyal to a side gives you a special force power (Protection/Deadly Sight.) I should probably play the game again to Force Lightning the hell of out everyone :)

If you run on Windows 7 or older you might be fine. 8 or 10, give it a try! It's too great a game to pass on just because if might" not run well on your rig."

I first played Dark Forces II as a child and it has always been one of my favorite games of all time.  For its time, it is a great game that possesses a terrific storyline. I can run it on Windows 7 without any problems, but if issues exist, it is possible to launch the game in compatibility mode.  My only complaint is their negligence with the soundtrack because the game features an absolutely incredible soundtrack.  However, it is a very easy fix.  The soundtrack can be patched; it is found here:

https://steamcommunity.com/app/32380/discussions/0/540740501398048712/

Follow the instructions to restore the soundtrack and enjoy the game!

reviewText: I remember playing the demo of this game when I was a kid, so I was very happy to see it on the steam store, and very cheap at that. This game is absolutely fantastic, but the game is very old. Because of this, the game may occaisonally crash when you pause/try to return to the game. It may also be difficult navigating the menus to try to get your controls just right. Other than than, this game is SOLID, and the cutscenes are AWESOME. It's a shame that multiplayer doesn't work, however. YES.
May require some effort to get running, and uses some unconventional keybindings/controls, but is still a gem. Those ♥♥♥♥ing wasp things still ♥♥♥♥ing terrify me.

The sequel to Star Wars: Dark Forces, now with live action cutscenes, lightsabers, Force Powers and Jedi! This game is another nostalgic piece to my 90’s gaming history and once again, another classic in the Star Wars gaming lineup. Once again, it features Kyle Katarn and his journey to becoming a Jedi and stopping Jerec, the main antagonist from becoming all-powerful. The game also does what its predecessor did not do: gives you some moral choices which affect the ending. The cutscenes are fairly comical (especially Jerec), even though the story is once again, in my opinion, fairly dark. Another outstanding game in an outstanding series of games from LucasArts so I recommend you just buy the entire Jedi Knight series.


*The game requires DosBox however, with the Steam download, everything will be set up for you to enjoy as soon as the game is downloaded.

Story/Characters:
You continue to follow Kyle Katarn in his quest for continuing to kick ♥♥♥ and saving the galaxy. Characters are given live actors which is either good or bad as your mileage may vary. Looking back at the cutscenes, I find them enjoyable.

Gameplay:
For the first several levels, you will be doing the old shooting and scooting until you get your lightsaber. From there, its hacking and slashing to victory with Force powers mixed in. The actions you do in-game will affect the “path” you will go down, either with the Light or Dark Side. This includes saving civilians and making choices in the main storyline. As with the last game, you will be fighting mini bosses in the form of Jerec’s Sith cronies. The lightsaber fights are awkward in my experience, as the hit detection seems to be off so you will end up just flailing your weapon around like a madman hoping to get a hit. There are some cool Force powers available however, ones that were not seen in the movies which is a bonus!

Graphics:
Once again, your mileage will vary. Either you like the 2D pixels of Dark Forces, or the angular and stiff 3D appearance of Dark Forces 2… pick your poison. Regardless, it gets the job done as it is oddly satisfying to see sparks fly when you hit the walls with your lightsaber. I did get this extremely annoying color glitch and it seems many old games have this issue (Starcraft), where the colors all turn into a headache inducing, blinding neon such as bright teal and pink. I had to mess with the graphical options in-game which I believe was 3D acceleration and make sure the game ran with Admin powers with the compatibility options enabled.

Sound/Music:
Enemies make the appropriate noises as they are dismembered by Kyle’s lightsaber of justice or riddled with bolts from the Repeater Rifle. Guns and the lightsaber make their iconic sounds. Lightsabers make their crackling noises as they strike each other in the boss duels, or thermal detonators going off in that Rodian’s face. The music is excellent as it usually is in Star Wars games… the Imperial March is as good as it was in the 90’s, as it is now.

Controls:
The game allows you to use a joystick or the standard keyboard and mouse. I prefer the latter but I do believe I remember playing it with the joystick when I was a kid. (Note: I did not get very far.) You may also customize hotkeys from everything from moving to weapons to force powers.

Replay value:
You may play through the Dark and Light side paths and try out all the Force powers but there are no achievements or any real incentives to play over and over.

Online:
The ancestor to Jedi Knight Jedi Outcast’s multiplayer. Nowadays, there may be some group somewhere in a galaxy far, far away playing this multiplayer if you look hard enough but I have never played it.

---

***If there are any mistakes to the facts pertaining to the game, please let me know. Also, if you have further questions not covered by the review, or if something were unclear, I will try to clarify as best as possible. Thanks!

Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II is the second game in the Jedi Knight Series.  With some new tech in the engine, actually its a whole new engine.  Some keen ideas in the story, and a few role-playing game elements mixed in.  Jedi Knight is a visible step up from the path that Dark Forces paved.  But just how much of a step is it, and will it surpass its predecessors Breakdown?

Jedi Knight, in my opinion, has some of the best story telling I’ve seen in games of its era.  It uses what has almost become a lost art, full motion video.  So many games today are switching over to scripted sequences that are rendered right in the game with the engine carrying the load.  While this can be a great tool for the story telling, at times the better tool is a FMV sequence.  The other great thing about Jedi Knight’s FMV’s are that they use live actors.  Actual people interacting with the CGI characters at the CGI locations.  That does a great job of putting you in the world with a small graphic budget.

Jedi Knight had very little compatibility issues, I simply installed it within Steam and in minutes was playing.  At first I had some interesting graphical problems, but with a little help from the Steam Community I got things working in fine order.  The resolution is changeable, but 1280 x 1024 is the highest it goes.  Which was not issues for me, since that’s what I operate with these days.

The game does play full screen, but it goes windowed in between levels and to show the FMV’s.  This sometimes caused issues where the full screen shows a blinking or faded border.  Not a game breaker, but was just an eye-sore.

Controls were a bit clunky, especially the lightsaber combat.  Fighting Storm Troopers was easy enough, but once you had to fight another Jedi it became a real conflict.  There was a definite delay from mouse-click to saber-swing, which made fighting the more challenging foes that much more challenging.  Also Jedi Knight has a auto-aim feature, something akin to the games predecessors, like Doom and Quake.  You only need aim in the general direction and the game will make sure the target is hit.  There are times where this is great and brings the skill level of the game down a notch or two, and a couple points where its an annoyance.

The grenades, or Thermal Detonators as the game would call them, even though actual Thermal Detonators would be far more powerful than what appears in the game.  Either way, they are virtually useless.  A simple click while holding one will practically drop it at your feet.  You throw them at an odd arc that I was unable to get the hang of during my play.  By holding down the fire button you can throw the Det further, but the angles were too hard for me to master and I typically just threw it into the wall or ceiling.

Jedi Knight has a Light/Dark pseudo system.  There is a point in the story where you make the choice of Light or Dark.  This choice is made for you, based on your actions up to that point.  If you were bad and killed too many non-hostile NPC’s then you’ll go the dark route.  I was actually bummed when I got the dark route.  I’d known I had killed a few non-hostiles, but had hoped it wasn’t too many.  And unfortunately I had learned about the prospect of different endings too late into the game, and didn’t want to start it all over again.  So I had just been hoping for the best.

The levels are fairly par for the time.  Mostly inside buildings, with doors, switches, and decent lighting.   Most of the maps have you searching for a key or switch to unlock the other side of the map.  Often this is easy enough, however there were a couple times where the door or switch was annoyingly hard to locate.  In many cases doors are simply a different sheet metal looking texture, and have no marking to show its a door.  And switches can be found in some very strange places.  There was many a time where I strafed walk along a wall rapidly tapping the ‘Use’ key.  Jedi Knight also makes sure to fill the Star Wars cliche of massive bottomless chasms to fall into.

The maps are typicality very large, you can tell the developers were going for that classic Star Wars feel of large spaces.  Many times you can see out windows or over ledges to these vast expanses.   These must have looked nicer years ago.  Because now I feel a lot of the effect is lost in the lower end graphics.  You can clearly see the repeating textures and where the map surface ends and the skybox begins.  Sometimes this is hidden fairly well with fading, as a way to try and preserve the feel of distance.

Overall the game is pretty solid.  It has parts that have short comings, but they all fit together nicely.  Showing just how solid of a game it was back in its day.  It shows a good level of improvement from its predecessor, which raises hopes of a continues level of improvement into the rest of the series.  There are far worst games from the late nineties that you could play.

With a few exceptions, one of the biggest being the headaches some of these older games cause, I did enjoy my time with Jedi Knight.  It was nice to venture back in time with Kyle Katarn.  I know him well in many Star Wars novels, but finally get to take the time to really learn his backstory.

People interested in buying Dark Forces II will probably be concerned about compatibility. So, does it work? The answer is no, probably not. If your hardware supports DirectX 9.0 or above, Dark Forces II will experience numerous graphical errors. However, there is a user-made patch that forwards broken functions to working DX7 functions, solving any graphical errors. This patch should have been packaged with the steam version, considering most people who use steam probably have a graphics card that is less than seven-ish years old.

reviewText: Oldschool fun. Carrying on from DF. This time you get to learn about the force and the valley of the Jedi. Dated now but still fun

After several years of this game being completely broken on Steam, Disney Interactive has stepped up and released a patch.

Despite the fact that it predates their acquisition, despite the fact that it probably isn't a huge money maker, they did this. For that, they've earned my respect.

Before the patch, the game didn't work in fullscreen properly, the music was entirely missing, and was highly prone to crashing. The update has fixed all of these issues. There are still issues with 3D Acceleration mode, limiting you on the color depth, but I'm hoping those will be fixed as well.

Beyond the technical aspects, my review of the game follows:

This is an old game. It is not a pretty game, and it is not a polished game. It is a very good game for the time, and if you either grew up with it, or can go back and appreciate classic titles, it is well worth full asking price, let alone sale price. I grew up with the Jedi Knight series, so I'm applying a heavy helping of rose-tint nostalgia paste to my goggles.

That said, it is still a fun, though at times puzzling and confusing game. It's from that era of shooters where we were just starting to experiment with platforming elements and puzzles, and as a result, it can get very frustrating on both.

Quicksave is your friend, you will need it. The Medium and Hard difficulties are brutal, par for the course at the time. Those of you who grew up with 90s-early 2000s PC shooters know what to expect, and the game is a blast if you enjoy that kind of run-and-gun gameplay.

The story is fairly cheesy, read the accompanying novels, if you can find and stomach them, as they shed light on a lot of details the game glosses over.

Overall, before the update, I probably would only recommend this to hardcore fans of the series, but now that it works out of the box, I think I can recommend it for anyone who's interested in the history of the series or PC gaming in general.

Dark Forces II was, arguably, one of the best shooters of its day. Provided that you don't mind a bit of effort to get the game up and running properly, the follow-up to the original DOS classic is well worth a look, providing an excellent example of how great a licensed title can be and the capability of its now defunct developer LucasArts.

Jedi Knight places you once more in the role of Kyle Katarn, a battle-hardened, side-switching mercenary of the expanded universe. Taking place a short time after the events of Episode VI, a small corrupted faction of the Empire's remnants known as the Dark Jedi are in pursuit of the legendary Valley of the Jedi and the unstoppable power that it supposedly grants. With an obvious interest in tracking them down, the inevitable confrontation allows you a chance to avenge the death of his family.

A huge step-up in terms of narrative alone, JK is also a significant depature from its predecessor in most respects. Levels are now bigger and more sprawling than ever but not baffling to explore, and there are plenty of hidden surprises across the various locations of the campaign. Sound is no longer technically limited by the MIDI format of the early '90s and John Williams' score plays on top of all the classic sound effects taken straight from the films. Combat is more refined and easy to get into and enjoy, with an impressive range of weapons on offer rather than an over-reliance on the Stormtrooper's blaster rifle or thermal detonators. The introduction of lightsaber combat is also worthy of note, though is admittedly prone to clunky, hack-and-slash gameplay.

Unlike the atrocious in-engine rendering of Mysteries of the Sith, JK uses the classic (almost nostalgic) combination of live-action and early CGI to establish the fairly well written narrative during the frequent (and occasionally lengthy) cutscenes. Most of the cast seemed to have thoroughly enjoyed acting in them and in-game dialogue uses the same high quality voices, which is a nice touch.

As one who has never been that invested or interested in Star Wars, (I've only seen the six episodes once and have little interest in the reboots), I was pleasantly surprised at how enjoyable this turned out to be. Having picked up the entire Jedi Knight collection and Battlefront II during the recent sale, it's encouraging to see licensed titles that are actually decent and, more to the point, satisfying to play.

The game certainly does have compatibility issues, (considering it's age), and requires a decent amount of time to tweak, fix and optimise for modern PCs. Yet it is a relatively straight-forward process and there a plenty of excellent guides and tutorials available in the community hub here to help you get it going.

As a result, I really can recommend Jedi Knight - Dark Forces II; a shooter that caters to pretty much everyone. It is a vastly superior experience compared to the first yet still retains the depth and style of it's now non-canon lore. Star Wars fans will have an absolute blast playing through this, undoubtedly coming back for more playthroughs, and for those such as myself, it provides an excellent example of the '90s shooter and a worthy alternative to Doom or Quake. Thumbs up.

reviewText: Star Wars: Fark Forces II is considered a classic to many from the gaming community.  Released in 1997, this game ushered in a new era of gaming, specifically for the first person shooter, that was predicated by games such as Quake and Wolfenstein where simply running and gunning was the only play style that counted.  Then came Dark Forces II and its ability to deliver gaming narrative, something that had not previously been seen in the shooter genre, with interactive storytelling through live action cut scenes and a storyline that could actually be influenced based upon your actions throughout the game.  While this aspect was great, the gameplay itself carrys Jedi Knight far as well.  With solid controls, impressive sounds and music that come direct from the Star Wars universe, great visuals for a game released in 1997, and an array of weapons and powers that create multiple play sytles and tactics, Star Wars Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II is a game that continues to stand the test of time.  Thanks to it, games such as Half-Life and the like (the story based shooter) were able to become a legitimized powerhouse in the gaming community and continue to rule the shooter community.  Very much worth the $4.99 Steam price tag.  May the Force be with you!

The game is set one year after the events of Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi. Former mercenary Kyle Katarn meets an info broker droid named 8t88 who informs Katarn that is father, Morgan, was killed by Jerec, a Dark Jedi with plans of rebuilding the Empire. Kyle is given a disk from 8t88 that only a droid in his father's home can read. Kyle Katarn sets out to find this droid and put an end to Jerec's plans to keep the galaxy at peace.

Dark Forces II much like its predecessor is a First Person Shooter, but now you are given the option to use a 3rd person camera if you so desire. The main game is divided into 21 levels, each with an objective and are completed in order.

reviewText:
If you can get over the graphics then you'll likely enjoy this game if you're a Star Wars fan.
The gameplay and story holds up pretty well for such an old game.
After the first few levels you can start earning points to skill up force powers that can be neutral, light or dark. Which side you choose will determine the outcome of the story (Light side is canon in the series of games). You get 10 different weapons ranging from fists to rail gun to lightsaber.
There are a number of boss fights versus Dark Jedi which can be pretty challenging if you don't know how to beat them (for example the neutral Force Seeing ability will make the second boss fight a lot easier).
You also travel to different planets starting with Nar Shaddaa.
Beware of the scary squid on level 4. That experience scarred me the first time I played the game over 10 years ago.

reviewText:
The force hasn't aged well


Dark forces 2 was the first star wars game I've played. I rememeber going to the library, burrowing and playing through it. I couldn't get past the first level back then though... After over a decade and having played the rest of the jedi knight series (Played a bit of dark forces 1 and completed the rest), I thought it would be nice to return to this game. In Dark forces 2, you play as Kyle Katarn, an ex-imperial stormtrooper who is trying to get some payback on the people responsible for killing his father.


The Good- Wide range of weapons = including pistol, blasters, smg, grenades, bowcaster, rocket launcher, lightsaber etc.
- Light Sabre battles
- Good environment variety = You will go to canyons, farmsteads, imperial bases, Nar Shadaa and many other places across your adventure.
- 21 single player missions = composed of around 7 boss battles and 14 standaard levels.
- Lots of hidden secrets in each level
- Different endings based on force allignment
- Decent number of force powers
- Classic star wars sound effects
- Decent, although cheesy, story = Mainly due to the not so great acting by the characters.
- Has multiplayer mode
- Wide range of foes = Including stormies, officers, rodians, gamoreans, bugs, walkers.


The Bad- Constant crashes when launching game for windows 8 and up (can be fixed though).
- Constant crashes when choosing to restart level.
- Ocassional crashes when saving/loading.
- Menu screen and cutscenes does not have wide screen support (can be fixed apparently).
- May need walkthrough as you will get lost trying to find where to go.
- Some annoying/unfair boss fights.
- Missing background music = You can mod it back in, but doesn't loop.
- Poor map = you can't use it to navigate where you are or where you need to go.
- You can only upgarde force powers at the end of the level = becomes a major problem in boss fights when certain powers can make your life alot easier.
- No quick saves


Final verdictSurprisingly, I enjoyed my playthrough of dark forces 2 despite the constant crashes and other obstacles I had to jump over. However, I strongly recommend you purchase the GOG version over this as it has better support for newer systems, runs better, DRM free and fixed a ton of glitches.

Along the way, Kyle discovers his latent connection to the Force and recieves a Lightsaber, allowing players the opportunity to play with a lightsaber for the first time in Star Wars Gaming History.

I don't think that Steam version of this game can give new players a chance to understand why is it a great game. First, there is no music - and music is so important here. Second - to run it properly, one has to go at some lengths.\n\nBut this title was extraordinary at its time for numerous reasons, and the biggest advantage is immersive and addictive gameplay. Paradoxically so, because graphics are pretty bad. But not many people remember that this game was out when 3D accelerators were still not something to take for granted. I first played Jedi Knight in the software renderer mode, and believe me, without 3D accelerator it looked better than any other title of the time. But the biggest thing about this game, as I think of it now, is its silence. You know, modern games are afraid to leave you alone, there are always some NPCs yelling at you, your guide telling you where to go, hints, messages and directions pop up from everywhere... It doesn't let you sink deep into the story and feel like you're there. But JK is the opposite. You are always on your own, which is emphasised by the gigantic proportions of the levels. The classic John Williams' score is tastefully woven into the atmosphere and is changing dynamically to make it even more dramatic. The cutscenes tie the story together and it all makes sense, you are no longer wandering from checkpoint to checkpoint for some obscure reasons, killing people; you always know your mission. Plus to that you carry the responsibility for your actions - the way you play will define your fate - become a Jedi or be consumed by the dark side of the Force. Add to it a lightsaber, the Force powers, and you forget about the graphics, and feel like it is all happening to you.
It is good for its age

A classic DOOM-clone and precursor to the majority of Star Wars games today.

Released in 1997, it proves still today that graphics are definitely not everything and provides a good lengthed story from the character Kyle Katarn, a rebel spy, as he follows the ways of the force to a jedi master or a sith lord. (your choice of power.)

An en masse of about 20 missions, they are relatively as mentioned to be lengthy; which provides evidence of the work and effort for engineering the game. There are also multiple weapons to choose from on your journey, including: the Stormtrooper blaster, satchel charges, wookie crossbow, railgun, etc, and of course, your lightsaber.

If you like Star Wars, classic late-90s graphics, and level-based games, then this is for you definitely.

For anyone who's remotely interested in the Star Wars expanded universe is going to want to play this.
It's hard for me to be unbias when writing a brief review because for me, I feel waves of nostalgia when playing this. But I'll try my best to list the good points and the bad.

I should note I finished the game in 9 hours, getting most of the secrets and watching all cutscenes.

Things I liked:

The music. The score comes straight from the films, so it's always going to be fantastic. This is of course if you choose to install the music with a patch, it dosen't come with the Steam version as standard.

The story. This is one of my favourite Star Wars stories, maybe it's the haunting voice of Rahn from the cutscene's or the fact all the bosses are genuinely interesting. I like the whole notion of the Valley of the Jedi.

The cutscene's. Let's be honest, alot of why this game was so popular was the live action cutscene, which were of the quality of something from the films. Wonderful actors like Jason Court bring the whole game to life.

Here's some things I didn't like:

I had trouble getting the game running well on new systems. There's some great guides to help you out there mind.

The cutscenes, for me, would only show in a small boarder window. I mean at least I got to watch them, but it's not ideal.

As I've already noted, the game does not come with the original music, you'll have to add it in a patch (it's well worth it)

As a shooter the game holds up very well, infact it's better than most modern day shooters. If you're worried because you've looked at the sceenshots and you're wondering if you could adapt to such an older game, I'd advise giving it a go.
But you should be warned, as most buying will most likely be running the game on newer systems, you may need to do some fiddling around to get the game running.

Truely a timeless cassic, if you're willing to get past it's age.

This is one of my all-time favorite games.  Seriously one of the best gaming experiences I ever had.  The Steam release, however, is not a good presentation of the game.

In Jedi Knight, the sequel to Dark Forces, you once again play as Kyle Katarn, a mercenary sometimes employed by the Rebels.  His father, once a Jedi who left the order, is killed for a secret he kept by a group of dark jedi.  Kyle must avenge his father and stop Jerec from rising to power as an omnipotent new Sith lord

This game stood apart from the FPS games of its time because of some innovations.  The use of a lightsaber, which serves as both an offensive and defensive weapon, was a bit deal.  Lots of games had melee weapons, but the lightsaber handled differently.  The force powers let you do things you could not do in any other FPS.  A rudimentary morality system allowed you to kill NPCs to change the outcome of the game, in an attempt to add a role-playing aspect.

As an FPS the game is satisfying enough.  There is actually a good story, told through cheesily acted cut scenes that still are more Star Wars than the prequels.  I find the focus of the Single Player campaign less about perfect aim (some of the weapons are kind of random, actually), but on cleverness and reflexes.  More often than not, the game insists on a stealth approach to some fights.  Like DF, JK is more interested in mental puzzles than being yet another Doom.  Every once in awhile, the game takes a break from the FPS mold for one-one-one (sometimes more) Jedi battles.

The game really shined in Multiplayer, though, back in its heyday.  A thriving mod community (thanks to a simple modification system) expanded on the already great gameplay.  Fighting an AI with a saber and force powers was one thing, playing a deathmatch against fully-powered Jedis was something amazing.

Unfortunately, this release, the Steam version, is not that version of the game.  Single Player is intact, with the exception of the music, which was redbook audio of John Williams' score.  It does leave something lacking to the campaign, as a result.  The Multiplayer system no longer works at all.  While this is not Steam's fault, it is something you should be aware when buying the game.  With the exception of painstaking modification and router configuration, this is now a single player game.  Which is a crying shame.

The executable for the game is also not always compatible with some patches and mods.  It can be frustrating trying to get the game to work with customizations.

Not all of the differences are bad, though.  The Steam version defaults to a windows GUI for menus, which might seem annoying, but addresses a bug in the original version of the game.  Instead of manually setting the workaround, Steam auto-applies it.  The game contols have been changed to WASD as default, as well.  And while this is not exclusive to Steam's release, this also applies to retail, the game has full native Widescreen support, and always has.  This seems a bit unusual for a 1997 game.

The two sequels that followed were worthy successors, but this was one of the best titles LucasArts made in their heyday.  It's definitely worth playing if you've never experienced it before.
It is good for its age

I can never finish most modern FPS games. They are either lacking and uninteresting in their gameplay or just a mindless run-and-gun game.
Rare are the games where the action is fast-paced, but not too fast or bugged. Gameplay that is fluid and quick, but not mindless.

For this reason, older games are often a breath of fresh air, as was the case with this game. I got this game through a Humble Bundle, and I am very pleased that I did.

The levels are fun and well thought out, making you think about what you are doing and how you are going to move forward. You also have to pay attention to detail, or risk spending time searching for that lever or button that will get you moving to the next area. At the same time movement is quick, ensuring that the levels don't drag out and get boring and tedious.

The action itself is much like newer games. There's a good spread of different weapons, although I tended to prefer the lightsaber once I god it. It was great fun slashing through my opponents. The boss fights are, at normal difficutly, easy and satisfying at the same time. The only exception to this was the final boss fight that was somewhat drawn out and got boring towards the end. Without spoiling anything, the endings depend on how you play and I felt that it made up for the somewhat crap boss fight.
I never really used the force powers much, except for Force Jump. I did use some in the final boss fight, but the actions is more than good enough without the powers and I had a great time blasting and slashing my opponents.

This game has the benefit of being a Star Wars game, and therefore able to use the appropriate music. I rarely enjoy the in-game music as much as I did in this game. The music itself is fantastic, well-timed and just that little bit extra that makes this game even greater. A lot of the time I was actually listening to, and enjoying the music as it really set the mood for a specific situation or level.
Towards the middle of the game I had constant flashbacks to the Nintendo 64 Star Wars game. Good times.

The graphics arent all that great, which is also obvious from the screenshots in the store page. That being said, I got used to it very quickly, and after about 10 minuts I wasn't offering that graphics a thoght. It felt just as natural as when playing Crysis or any other game (not that I enjoyed Crysis anywhere near as much as this game).
Also worth a mentions is the cutscenes. I really like this style of doing them and wish more games would do the same.


All in all, this is a very good game and I recommend it to any fans of FPS or Star Wars games without hesitation.

This game stood apart from the FPS games of its time because of some innovations.  The use of a lightsaber, which serves as both an offensive and defensive weapon, was a bit deal.  Lots of games had melee weapons, but the lightsaber handled differently.  The force powers let you do things you could not do in any other FPS.  A rudimentary morality system allowed you to kill NPCs to change the outcome of the game, in an attempt to add a role-playing aspect.

As an FPS the game is satisfying enough.  There is actually a good story, told through cheesily acted cut scenes that still are more Star Wars than the prequels.  I find the focus of the Single Player campaign less about perfect aim (some of the weapons are kind of random, actually), but on cleverness and reflexes.  More often than not, the game insists on a stealth approach to some fights.  Like DF, JK is more interested in mental puzzles than being yet another Doom.  Every once in awhile, the game takes a break from the FPS mold for one-one-one (sometimes more) Jedi battles.

The game really shined in Multiplayer, though, back in its heyday.  A thriving mod community (thanks to a simple modification system) expanded on the already great gameplay.  Fighting an AI with a saber and force powers was one thing, playing a deathmatch against fully-powered Jedis was something amazing.

Unfortunately, this release, the Steam version, is not that version of the game.  Single Player is intact, with the exception of the music, which was redbook audio of John Williams' score.  It does leave something lacking to the campaign, as a result.  The Multiplayer system no longer works at all.  While this is not Steam's fault, it is something you should be aware when buying the game.  With the exception of painstaking modification and router configuration, this is now a single player game.  Which is a crying shame.

The executable for the game is also not always compatible with some patches and mods.  It can be frustrating trying to get the game to work with customizations.

Not all of the differences are bad, though.  The Steam version defaults to a windows GUI for menus, which might seem annoying, but addresses a bug in the original version of the game.  Instead of manually setting the workaround, Steam auto-applies it.  The game contols have been changed to WASD as default, as well.  And while this is not exclusive to Steam's release, this also applies to retail, the game has full native Widescreen support, and always has.  This seems a bit unusual for a 1997 game.

The two sequels that followed were worthy successors, but this was one of the best titles LucasArts made in their heyday.  It's definitely worth playing if you've never experienced it before.

I am a fan of Star Wars and I have been since I was very young. This game came out when I was just a child and I never actually played this game back then, but I did enjoy countless hours of repeating the demo mission from the old free Mysteries of the Sith demo (MotS is the standalone expac for this game) over and over again, as well as the original Dark Forces. I then began playing Jedi Outcast a few years later, then Jedi Academy. Needless to say, I'm a HUGE fan of the Jedi Knight series as a whole.

This game has to be one of the most unique shooters out there for the sole reason of force powers and a lightsaber. For the time, this game had beautiful graphics, a remarkable art style that very strongly captured the Star Wars atmosphere, and combine that with the lightsaber/force powers, you take what would be an average 90s shooter and turn it into one of my favorite games of all time.

When I purchased this game two Christmas sales ago (with the Star Wars pack), I excitedly hopped onto Steam and installed this game first, and since then I've probably played through it over 50 times. It's not as if there's a lot of choice, as there isn't. Basically, you choose your force powers (and how proficient you are with them) as well as whether or not you kill innocents/droids. No, is is neither the choice nor secrets that keep me coming back to this game. It's purely because this is a GREAT game, even by today's standards.

Graphically, this game is definitely straight from the 90s with FMV cutscenes, blocky polygons, and low-res textures, which leads many people to opt into downloading graphical overhaul mods but I have not once wanted to change the graphics. Sure, they're an eyesore compared to today's games but they still have a nostalgic charm. Plus, as an aspiring developer myself, I am in awe at how they pulled off some of the effects by tapping into their creativity-- something modern devs need to take a look at. My favorite effect is the lightsaber, which uses animated sprites in just the right way to achieve the proper effect.

Gameplay-wise, this game runs pretty similar to modern shooters. The number keys select your weapons, you have jump, crouch, run, and activate buttons, you fire using your mouse. The only major difference between this and modern shooters is that there isn't an ironsights feature, nor do you have a separate key for grenades/explosives.

If you can get past some of the compatibility issues (I can't run in fullscreen on this PC which uses Windows 7), this game is worth every penny if you like Star Wars, shooters, and/or classic 90s games. In fact, the whole Dark Forces/Jedi Knight series is worth a purchase, as they're all great games with great stories and addicting gameplay/level design. I'd say this is my personal favorite in the whole series followed closely by Jedi Academy.

Finally got around to play Dark Forces 2 and they really stepped up their game in this one. You continue from the first game in a story that finally brings in the almighty lightsaber and Jedi. But wait they are killing innocents so they must be sith. No they’re Jedi, but they are “dark” Jedi. I don’t know the difference nor do I care, but I digress. I won’t get into the story, but you basically go around trying to find this droid who takes your stuff and you learn that some of that stuff holds info on the Jedi temples and that you are force prone. You get a kick ♥♥♥ light saber and begin to learn the ways of the force while encountering the “Dark Jedi” along the way.

Just like the first game you get a lot of weapons and that keeps the game relatively fresh and the learning of force powers makes it easy to get to certain places and obtain secrets as well as level progression. Unlike the first game you can actually look up. The game is now a more sophisticated first person shooter. The force powers are fun, but most of the time, or at least in my case, they were nothing more than helping you get from point A to point B. They didn’t assist you in combat all that much. I mean sure I could use force pull and take the enemies guns, or I could just pull out my own gun and shoot them while running in a circle because the AI can’t hit for ♥♥♥♥. Even in the fights with the Dark Jedi I just ran around and swung my saber and in later battles occasionally healed.

The story was good, the game was action packed, still had the confusing maps and navigation, but overall an enjoyable experience. Even though I went light side on my first play through I know you can go dark and get different powers and maybe even a different ending which means the game has replayability.

Overall I would rate this game an 8/10. Enjoyed the game, story was fine, and mechanics were introduced which made the game that more interesting.

My Advice, even though I didn’t, before you play this game go look for some mods. The game crashed a lot on me and the texture color could only be fixed by picking up something or hitting the ground with my saber. While this didn’t stop me from play it did get annoying. So before you play this just go online and find some mods to help make this game more of enjoyable experience for you.

That's not to say that Dark Forces was bad, it's just that I didn't adapt to it's odd control scheme as well as I do now a days, so I wasn't able to appreciate it's full glory at the time.
Dark Forces II on the other hand I picked right up on! I loved the ease of controls and the ability to look all around and jump, which contrary to many FPS's of today, was HIGHLY utilized in this title as it did not just have you running around horizontal land scapes, merely scaling a flight of stairs here and there, but it also had you carefully travelling across cat walks, being carried by a stream of water, scaling and decending sky scrapers and other large structures that seem go on forever (as Star Wars structures should), and on and on and on.
On top of this you not only get to run and gun and eventually pick up new weapons, but you also acquire force powers as the game goes on, and more than that, you can alter the outcome of the game based upon the the choices that you make within it. And if that's not enough... cut scenes, lots and lots of cut scenes to help push the story and your cuiosity foward as you progress from one unique level to the next.

What this lacks though is hi-def textures, the hi-def model pack, and the ability to run this under Wine. Also it may not be clear that you have to reverse the Y Axis in order to un-reverse look, and you also need to set it to use your 3D GFX card else the graphics will look like a gay pride parade.

That being said, it's worth the download, just don't expect it to be free of configuration needs, and don't expect it to look like a modern game, though map wise, it's got most of the modern ones beet, and the story ain't half bad either, I even read the book!
